commander.name: Général de Division Maurice Mathenet
commander.previous_service: Commander of Military Division of Meknès, Morocco

personnel_composition.note: Approximately 79% Maghrebi (North African), 21% French European composition

Somua S35.note: Best pre-war French tank still operational

halftracks.note: No halftracks in French colonial divisions; relied on trucks for infantry transport

Captured Italian FIAT 626.note: Captured from Italian forces in Tunisia

trucks.note: Severe shortage of spare parts for pre-war French vehicles; operational rate declining without American replacements

Canon de 75 modèle 1897.performance: Proven effective at Faïd Pass January 30, 1943

Canon de 47 mm SA mle 1937.effectiveness: Inadequate against Panzer IV and Tiger I

note_air_support: No organic air assets; air support provided by Allied air forces under coordinated command

supply_status.general_assessment: Poor - Antiquated pre-war equipment with severe spare parts shortages. Re-equipment with American weapons beginning late February/March 1943.
supply_status.logistics_note: Supply lines stretched from Algerian bases; dependent on British 1st Army logistics network

subordinate_units.composition: 79% Moroccan enlisted, 21% French officers and NCOs
79% Moroccan enlisted, 21% French officers and NCOs
79% Moroccan enlisted, 21% French officers and NCOs
subordinate_units.note: Commander specifically identified in historical sources
Medical, signals, supply, transport, maintenance units

tactical_doctrine.role: Defensive infantry division holding sectors of the Eastern Dorsal Mountains in central Tunisia
special_capabilities: North African troops well-adapted to desert conditions
Strong esprit de corps among Moroccan tirailleurs units
known_issues: Inadequate anti-tank capability versus 1943 German armor (Panzer IV, Tiger I)
Limited mechanization compared to German and British forces
Obsolete pre-war equipment with critical spare parts shortages
Artillery effective but limited in range and mobility
Poor coordination with Allied forces initially due to recent armistice
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Troops well-acclimated to North African terrain and climate; French colonial forces had extensive desert warfare experience from pre-war operations in Morocco and Algeria

key_engagements: Port-Lyautey (November 1942) - Initially opposed American landings during Operation Torch
Battle of Faïd Pass (January 30, 1943) - Defeated despite effective 75mm artillery fire
Battle of Zaghouan (May 12, 1943) - Obtained surrender of German Colonel Pfeiffer (21st Panzer Division Kampfgruppe commander) and Italian Colonel Agnelo
combat_history.command_relationships: Part of French XIX Corps under Lieutenant General Marie-Louis Koëltz; nominally under British 1st Army command but took operational orders from Général Juin (senior French commander North Africa)
combat_history.post_tunisia: Reorganized after Tunisia campaign ended May 13, 1943; elements contributed to formation of 2e Division d'Infanterie Marocaine (formed May 1, 1943) for Italian campaign

scenario_suitability: Mixed Allied operations requiring French colonial forces
special_rules: French colonial infantry: +1 morale in defensive positions
Inadequate AT: -2 modifier versus German armor
Canon de 75 mle 1897: High rate of fire (15-20 rpm) but limited range

source: British Military History - Tunisia 1942-1943 French Divisions
Chemins de Mémoire (French Ministry of Defense) - La campagne de Tunisie
Légion Étrangère archives - Jean Balazuc Tunisia Campaign history
Warfare History Network - French forces in Tunisia
US Army Historical Division - Tunisia Campaign (ibiblio.org)
known_gaps: Exact battalion and company-level organization not fully documented in available sources
Precise commander names for most subordinate units unknown
Exact operational vehicle counts estimated from organizational tables and attrition rates
Individual weapon counts calculated from standard French colonial division TO&E with adjustments for equipment shortages
validation.methodology: Combined historical research from verified non-Wikipedia sources with existing project French 1943-Q1 data. Equipment counts based on standard French colonial division TO&E adjusted for documented shortages and re-equipment timeline. Personnel composition ratios (79% Maghrebi) from historical records of North African colonial units.
validation.critical_note: This TO&E represents Division de Marche du Maroc (formed November 1942), NOT 2e Division d'Infanterie Marocaine (formed May 1, 1943). The latter did not exist during 1943-Q1 timeframe.
